Does self-inflicted pain change the level of pain you can handle, or how you feel it? I used to self-injure, and don't read if you think you'll be triggered one of the things I did was burn my arms with a clothing iron. At some points, I turned the temperature knob up to the highest possibility and when it was on my skin, there was steam rising and I still kept the iron on. It hurt, but it wasn't terrible. I've also cut huge gashes that were 1-3 inches wide on my legs, no exaggeration. It's not like I enjoyed it. Mainly I just freaked out because I didn't mean to cut that insanely wide, but it was a bendy blade cut out of a shaving razor and got caught on the skin, as I'm not someone who cut slowly and methodically, as self-injurers seem to be portrayed, but fast and deep. I remember being more freaked out and scared than anything else though. I had never seen cuts that big and I just had a towel over it hoping it would stop bleeding and sad it was so bad but I couldn't wake my mom up and/or go to the hospital, not the pain. And after some of the clothing iron burns, sometimes I would feel drugged, like I literally couldn't turn down the corners of my mouth and stop smiling, and wanted to dance around listening to music. But I swear, I'm not a masochist; when something happens by accident, I get so freaked out, I can't even look at the cut. So I don't really know how to label this in terms of handling or enjoying or disliking pain!

We teach pain in Japanese Ju-Jitisu. If you apply constant pressure on a pressure point, you can train your brain to slowly, weaken the effects of the pain generated. Withstanding, it for longer, useful during a fight.

If you start to pulse between deep and shallow pressure on that same point, your brain struggles to adapt and control the pain. So the pain feels much worse. Also, pain is not physical. It's just an electrical signal to notify your brain, for immediate attention, to that area. With enough training and meditation, you can suppress a lot of pain messages.

I feel as though swearing has no specific effect on the toleration of pain, it is obviously on a case by case basis... they literally created a video about pain disproving any solid variable in pain factorization. As we see here the one on the left is more resistant to pain, but even then he is not the greatest at handling it. He seems to be average or maybe even below average at handling pain. The problem with the swearing experiment is that yelling can yield the same effect, without vulgarities, and even then, people swearing when taking pain have still given up much before people who haven't, it is always case-by-case, they state that in one of their previous videos. Contradicting themselves and in the end not really proving anything, this title was misleading, as it was hardly even credible for an opinion, it should have been marked as a little game or challenge... and not try to be shipped off as a fact.
